column10797: the very first interview he's given since Tuesday's contests in North Carolina and Indiana. Senator, welcome. OBAMA: Good to see you, Wolf. BLITZER: Here is the cover, And the Winner Is..." That's a picture of you. What do you think? OBAMA: Well
column10799: I think -- I don't want to be jinxed. We've still got some work to do. BLITZER: It's almost like you got the cover of "Sports Illustrated." Is that what you're -- you're nervous about that? OBAMA: Exactly. Exactly right. We've got six more contests left. And then we've got a lot of work to do to bring the party together
column10802: we felt very good about our win in North Carolina on Tuesday. I think we ran a terrific campaign in Indiana. And it was a virtual tie. And
column10803: if you look at where the race is at this point
column10804: I think we have seen voters across the country say they are ready for change. They are feeling real anxiety about the economy. And they have come to recognize that
column10805: unless we change how Washington is done. It's going to be very hard to deliver on a smarter energy policy. It's going to be hard to -- to provide health care for people who need it or make college more affordable. And I think our campaign has benefited from it. And
column10807: I'm looking forward to bringing this party together and going after John McCain in the fall
column10810: getting this country on the right track. BLITZER: It's been intense in the primaries. But you realize it's going to be much more intense in the next chapter
column10812: given the differences between you and John McCain. Are you ready for this next phase? OBAMA: I'm actually looking forward to it

column10815: she's -- she's going to be actively campaigning. If I'm fortunate enough to be the nominee

column11525: and may God Bless America. It is my privilege to join in this week's Independence Day celebration
column11526: and in honoring those who have stood up with courage and conviction for Cuban liberty. I'm going to take this opportunity to speak about Cuba
column11527: and also U.S. policy toward the Americas more broadly. We meet here united in our unshakeable commitment to freedom. And it is fitting that we reaffirm that commitment here in Miami. In many ways
column11528: Miami stands as a symbol of hope for what's possible in the Americas. Miami's promise of liberty and opportunity has drawn generations of immigrants to these shores
column11529: sometimes with nothing more than the clothes on their back. It was a similar hope that drew my own father across an ocean
column11530: in search of the same promise that our dreams need not be deferred because of who we are
column11532: or where we come from. Here
column11534: that promise can join people together. We take common pride in a vibrant and diverse democracy
column11535: and a hard-earned prosperity. We find common pleasure in the crack of the bat
column11536: in the rhythms of our music
column11537: and the ease of voices shifting from Spanish or Creole or Portuguese to English. These bonds are built on a foundation of shared history in our hemisphere. Colonized by empires
column11538: we share stories of liberation. Confronted by our own imperfections
column11539: we are joined in a desire to build a more perfect union. Rich in resources
column11540: we have yet to vanquish poverty. What all of us strive for is freedom as FDR described it. Political freedom. Religious freedom. But also freedom from want
column11541: and freedom from fear. At our best
column11542: the United States has been a force for these four freedoms in the Americas. But if we're honest with ourselves
column11543: we'll acknowledge that at times we've failed to engage the people of the region with the respect owed to a partner. When George Bush was elected
column11544: he held out the promise that this would change. He raised the hopes of the region that our engagement would be sustained instead of piecemeal. He called Mexico our most important bilateral relationship
column11545: and pledged to make Latin America a "fundamental commitment" of his presidency. It seemed that a new 21st century era had dawned. Almost eight years later
column11546: those high hopes have been dashed. Since the Bush Administration launched a misguided war in Iraq
column11547: its policy in the Americas has been negligent toward our friends
column11549: disinterested in the challenges that matter in peoples' lives
column11550: and incapable of advancing our interests in the region. No wonder
column11552: that demagogues like Hugo Chavez have stepped into this vacuum. His predictable yet perilous mix of anti-American rhetoric
column11554: and checkbook diplomacy offers the same false promise as the tried and failed ideologies of the past. But the United States is so alienated from the rest of the Americas that this stale vision has gone unchallenged
column11555: and has even made inroads from Bolivia to Nicaragua. And Chavez and his allies are not the only ones filling the vacuum. While the United States fails to address the changing realities in the Americas
column11556: others from Europe and Asia  notably China  have stepped up their own engagement. Iran has drawn closer to Venezuela
column11557: and just the other day Tehran and Caracas launched a joint bank with their windfall oil profits. That is the record  the Bush record in Latin America  that John McCain has chosen to embrace. Senator McCain doesn't talk about these trends in our hemisphere because he knows that it's part of the broader Bush-McCain failure to address priorities beyond Iraq. The situation has changed in the Americas
column11558: but we've failed to change with it. Instead of engaging the people of the region
column11559: we've acted as if we can still dictate terms unilaterally. We have not offered a clear and comprehensive vision
column11560: backed up with strong diplomacy. We are failing to join the battle for hearts and minds. For far too long
column11561: Washington has engaged in outdated debates and stuck to tired blueprints on drugs and trade
column11562: on democracy and development -- even though they won't meet the tests of the future. The stakes could not be higher. It is time for us to recognize that the future security and prosperity of the United States is fundamentally tied to the future of the Americas. If we don't turn away from the policies of the past
column11563: then we won't be able to shape the future. The Bush Administration has offered no clear vision for this future
column11564: and neither has John McCain. So we face a clear choice in this election. We can continue as a bystander
column11565: or we can lead the hemisphere into the 21st century. And when I am President of the United States
column11566: we will choose to lead. It's time for a new alliance of the Americas. After eight years of the failed policies of the past
column11567: we need new leadership for the future. After decades pressing for top-down reform
column11568: we need an agenda that advances democracy
column11570: and opportunity from the bottom up. So my policy towards the Americas will be guided by the simple principle that what's good for the people of the Americas is good for the United States. That means measuring success not just through agreements among governments
column11571: but also through the hopes of the child in the favelas of Rio
column11572: the security for the policeman in Mexico City
column11573: and the answered cries of political prisoners heard from jails in Havana. The first and most fundamental freedom that we must work for is political freedom. The United States must be a relentless advocate for democracy. I grew up for a time in Indonesia. It was a society struggling to achieve meaningful democracy. Power could be undisguised and indiscriminate. Too often
column11575: and was unaccountable to the people. Some still had good reason to fear a knock on the door. There is no place for this kind of tyranny in this hemisphere. There is no place for any darkness that would shut out the light of liberty. Here we must heed the words of Dr. King

column11577: there has been injustice in Cuba. Never
column11579: have the people of Cuba known freedom. Never
column11580: in the lives of two generations of Cubans
column11581: have the people of Cuba known democracy. I won't stand for this injustice

column11591: and continue a policy that's done nothing to advance freedom for the Cuban people. That's the political posture that John McCain has chosen

column11601: but only when we have an opportunity to advance the interests of the United States

column11607: rule out a course of action that could advance the cause of liberty. We've heard enough empty promises from politicians like George Bush and John McCain. I will turn the page. column11614: but we need steady action. We must put forward a vision of democracy that goes beyond the ballot box. We should increase our support for strong legislatures
column11620: and the rule of law. That is how we can support democracy that is strong and sustainable not just on an election day

The Haitian people have suffered too long under governments that cared more about their own power than their peoples' progress and prosperity. It's time to press Haiti's leaders to bridge the divides between them. And it's time to invest in the economic development that must underpin the security that the Haitian people lack. And that is why the second part of my agenda will be advancing freedom from fear in the Americas. For too many people in our hemisphere
column11622: security is absent from their daily lives. And for far too long
column11623: Washington has been trapped in a conventional thinking about Latin America and the Caribbean. From the right
column11624: we hear about violent insurgents. From the left
column11625: we hear about paramilitaries. This is the predictable debate that seems frozen in time from the 1980s. You're either soft on Communism or soft on death squads. And it has more to do with the politics of Washington than beating back the perils that so many people face in the Americas. The person living in fear of violence doesn't care if they're threatened by a right-wing paramilitary or a left-wing terrorist; they don't care if they're being threatened by a drug cartel or a corrupt police force. They just care that they're being threatened
column11626: and that their families can't live and work in peace. That is why there will never be true security unless we focus our efforts on targeting every source of fear in the Americas. That's what I'll do as President of the United States. For the people of Colombia  who have suffered at the hands of killers of every sort  that means battling all sources of violence. When I am President
column11627: we will continue the Andean Counter-Drug Program
column11628: and update it to meet evolving challenges. We will fully support Colombia's fight against the FARC. We'll work with the government to end the reign of terror from right wing paramilitaries. We will support Colombia's right to strike terrorists who seek safe-haven across its borders. And we will shine a light on any support for the FARC that comes from neighboring governments. This behavior must be exposed to international condemnation
column11630: and  if need be  strong sanctions. It must not stand. We must also make clear our support for labor rights
column11632: and that means meaningful support for Colombia's democratic institutions. We've neglected this support  especially for the rule of law  for far too long. In every country in our hemisphere  including our own  governments must develop the tools to protect their people. Because if we've learned anything in our history in the Americas
column11633: it's that true security cannot come from force alone. Not as long as there are towns in Mexico where drug kingpins are more powerful than judges. Not as long as there are children who grow up afraid of the police. Not as long as drugs and gangs move north across our border
